questions.question_text: Which option shows the steps to install the Console in a Kubernetes Cluster?

choices.C: Download the Console and Defender image Download YAML for Defender from the document site Deploy Defender YAML using kubectl
choices.A: Download the Console and Defender image Generate YAML for Defender Deploy Defender YAML using kubectl
choices.B: Download and extract release tarball Generate YAML for Console Deploy Console YAML using kubectl
choices.D: Download and extract release tarball Download the YAML for Console Deploy Console YAML using kubectl

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Download and extract the release tarball of Prisma Cloud Console.
Generate the YAML configuration file for the Console.
Deploy the Console YAML configuration file using kubectl command to apply the configuration to the Kubernetes cluster.

choices.A: Configure a function scan policy from the Defend/Vulnerabilities/Functions page.
choices.D: Configure a serverless auto-protect rule for the functions.
choices.C: Configure a manually embedded Lambda Defender.
choices.B: Configure serverless radar from the Defend/Compliance/Cloud Platforms page.

discussion.content: Based on the demo and resource, D is correct.

questions.question_text:
A customer has a requirement to automatically protect all Lambda functions with runtime protection.
What is the process to automatically protect all the Lambda functions?

choices.D: An administrator who needs to access the Prisma Cloud API can use SSO after configuration.
choices.B: Okta, Azure Active Directory, PingID, and others are supported via SAML.
choices.C: An administrator can configure different Identity Providers (IdP) for all the cloud accounts that Prisma Cloud monitors.
choices.A: Prisma Cloud supports IdP initiated SSO, and its SAML endpoint supports the POST and GET methods.

questions.question_text: Which statement accurately characterizes SSO Integration on Prisma Cloud?

discussion.content:
For Exclusion B (Tricky question about A).

On Prisma Cloud, you can enable single sign-on (SSO) using an Identity Provider (IdP) that supports Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML), such as Okta, Microsoft Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS), Azure Active Directory (AD), Google, or OneLogin. You can configure only one IdP for all the cloud accounts that Prisma Cloud monitors.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/prisma/prisma-cloud/prisma-cloud-admin/manage-prisma-cloud-administrators/setup-sso-integration-on-prisma-cloud

Selected Answer: B
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/prisma/prisma-cloud/prisma-cloud-admin/manage-prisma-cloud-administrators/setup-sso-integration-on-prisma-cloud

'Prisma Cloud supports IdP initiated SSO, and itâ€™s SAML endpoint supports the POST method only.'

Selected Answer: B
SAML endpoint supports the POST method only

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Match the service on the right that evaluates each exposure type on the left.
(Select your answer from the pull-down list. Answers may be used more than once or not at all.)
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
The Data Security capabilities on Prisma Cloud enable you to discover and classify data stored in
AWS S3 buckets and protect accidental exposure, misuse, or sharing of sensitive data. To identify
and detect confidential and sensitive data, Prisma Cloud Data Security integrates with Palo Alto
Networks Enterprise DLP service and provides built-in data profiles. These profiles include data
patterns that match sensitive information such as PII, health care, financial information, and
intellectual property. In addition to protecting your confidential and sensitive data, the data profiles
protect against known and unknown (zero-day) malware threats, using the Palo Alto Networks
WildFire service.
